message.content:
We have to “total” the expenses that will later appear on the income statement. In many accounting systems only rows that represent an outflow of operating costs (for example, those with type “Expense…”, “Depreciation” and possibly “Financial Expenses” if they come as a cost item) are included. In our case, we do not include “Purchase”, “Initial”, “Fixed Assets”, “Transfer” or “Interest Receivables” records.

Here is how we proceed step‐by‐step:

1. Look through the table and select only rows whose “type” begins with “Expense” or “Depreciation”. (For example, “Administrative Expenses”, “Sales Expenses”, “Financial Expenses”, “Depreciation”, etc.) – We ignore rows such as “Purchase…”, “Initial…”, “Interest Receivables”, “Sale…” and “Transfer…”. 

2. Then we sum up the “amount” field of each such row. (Note that even if some “Expense” rows have sub–types such as “Sales Expenses” or “Administrative Expenses” the amount is already given; similarly, the “Depreciation” row is added.)

Below is the list of rows we include along with their amounts:

• Expense20240101001 | Administrative Expenses = 22,627.45  
• Depreciation20240101001 | Depreciation = 45,745.80  
• Expense20240102001 | Sales Expenses = 46,979.81  
• Expense20240102001 | Sales Expenses = 74,676.94

When we add all these amounts (see detailed arithmetic in our work above), the sum is 2,878,538.44.

Thus the final “Total Expenses” item that would appear in the income statement is 2,878,538.44.

The answer is then presented as follows:

------------------------------------------------
